questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with edema for last few months. It started on face but now it is generalized with pedal edema and ascites. He showed good response to steroids. His was RBS 112 mg/dl. On urine examination massive proteinuria was seen. On light microscopy the findings were unremarkable, on electron microscopy of kidney biopsy, effacement of podocytes was seen. Identify the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Minimal change disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Minimal Change Disease is characterized by generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and unremarkable light microscopy findings, with podocyte effacement seen on electron microscopy. It typically responds well to corticosteroids.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Polio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad? (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars

options.label: B
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars

options.label: C
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors

options.label: D
options.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.correct_answer: D. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors, and it is a diagnostic feature of late congenital syphilis.

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in FEV1> 15% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.correct_answer: C. Day- night variation of FEV1 > 15%
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 15%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in FEV1 > 15% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: What are the recommended actions according to Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines for a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid? (INICET MAY 2023) lntrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder lntratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a newborn with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, gentle suction is applied to the nose and mouth if the baby is vigorous, and PPV is administered if the baby is non-vigorous after the initial steps of resuscitation.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: What is the karyotype associated with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 47, XY (+21)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common non-preventable cause of intellectual disability and is associated with characteristic physical findings such as a single palmar crease.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aqueductal stenosis is the leading cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns due to the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ectopic ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female with continuous dribbling of urine since birth, despite normal voiding, due to the abnormal insertion of the ureter outside the bladder.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with palpable purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain. A diagnosis of IgA vasculitis was made. What is the indication for starting steroids in Henoch Schonlein Purpura? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), steroids are indicated for the management of gastrointestinal symptoms such as severe abdominal pain or bleeding.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper limb and the lower limb. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coxsackie viral infection can cause Hand-foot-and-mouth disease with associated viral meningitis, characterized by vesicular lesions on the palms, soles, and oral cavity, along with normal glucose and elevated lymphocytes in CSF.

questions.text: A child presented with intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a “crumpled paper appearance.” What is your best diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.

options.label: B
options.text: Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.

options.label: C
options.text: Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.

options.label: D
options.text: Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask.

questions.correct_answer: A. Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/ minutes despite effective compression and ventilation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epinephrine is administered in neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation and chest compressions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest indicator of pathological gastroesophageal reflux in infants (GERD)? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Respiratory symptoms

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Recurrent respiratory symptoms such as wheezing, stridor, chronic cough, and apnea are the earliest indicators of pathological gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) in infants. These symptoms arise due to the aspiration of gastric contents, which irritates the airways. GERD can lead to complications like failure to thrive and recurrent pulmonary issues. While postprandial regurgitation is common in infants, it does not necessarily indicate pathological reflux unless accompanied by other symptoms.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Postprandial regurgitation: This is a common symptom of physiological reflux and does not alone indicate GERD.
  • • Option B. Postprandial regurgitation:
  • • Option C. Upper GI bleed: This is a more specific but less common indicator of severe esophagitis due to GERD.
  • • Option C. Upper GI bleed:
  • • Option D. Esophageal stricture: This is a late complication of untreated GERD and not an early indicator.
  • • Option D. Esophageal stricture:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent respiratory symptoms are the earliest indicators of pathological gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) in infants.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hurler disease.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hurler disease, a form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, presents with coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious nasal discharge, and is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: Which of the following positions of the appendix is likely to present with suprapubic pain in a patient with acute appendicitis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The subcaecal position is most likely to cause suprapubic pain among the given options. When the appendix is positioned below the cecum, it can extend inferiorly toward the pelvic brim. Inflammation in this position may spread downward, causing irritation to pelvic structures and resulting in suprapubic discomfort. This anatomical relationship explains why subcaecal appendicitis can present with symptoms similar to pelvic appendicitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pre-ileal - When the appendix is anterior to the terminal ileum, it typically presents with classic right iliac fossa pain at McBurney's point, not suprapubic discomfort.
  • • Option A.
  • • Pre-ileal
  • • Option B. Post-ileal - Post-ileal appendicitis typically causes ill-defined tenderness immediately to the right of the umbilicus and may present with features of diarrhea and retching rather than suprapubic pain.
  • • Option B.
  • • Post-ileal
  • • Option D. Retrocecal - The most common position (74%), retrocecal appendicitis typically causes deep tenderness in the loin with possible psoas irritation, manifesting as flank or back pain rather than suprapubic discomfort.
  • • Option D.
  • • Retrocecal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anatomical positioning of a subcaecal appendix allows for extension toward the pelvic region, making it most likely among the given options to cause suprapubic symptoms when inflamed.

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Measure central cyanosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pulse oximeter is useful in various neonatal and resuscitation settings to monitor oxygen saturation and heart rate, but it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Biliverdin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The greenish-black color of the first stool (meconium) in a newborn is due to biliverdin, a bile pigment.

questions.text: How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022) Airway and breathing IV Lorazepam Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone IV Fosphenytoine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

questions.text: An infant of a diabetic mother with a birth weight of 3.8 kg presents with seizures 16 hours after birth. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2014 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypoglycemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Neonatal hypoglycemia is a common cause of seizures in infants of diabetic mothers. These infants are at increased risk of hypoglycemia due to maternal hyperglycemia leading to fetal hyperinsulinemia. When the maternal glucose supply is removed at birth, the high insulin levels can cause a rapid drop in the infant's blood glucose. Hypoglycemia can present with symptoms such as jitteriness, lethargy, and seizures. Although hypocalcemia can also cause seizures in these infants, hypoglycemia is more common within the first 24 hours of life.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hypocalcemia: While a possible cause, it is less common than hypoglycemia as an initial cause of seizures in infants of diabetic mothers.
  • • Option
  • • B. Hypocalcemia:
  • • Option C. Birth asphyxia : This can cause neonatal seizures but is less likely in the context of an otherwise stable infant with a specific maternal history.
  • • Option
  • • C. Birth asphyxia
  • • Option D. Intraventricular hemorrhage : This is a potential cause of neonatal seizures but less likely compared to hypoglycemia in this scenario.
  • • Option
  • • D. Intraventricular hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia is the most likely cause of seizures in an infant of a diabetic mother presenting within the first 24 hours of life.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 8

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: 1-month-old baby came with complaints of projectile vomiting with an olive-shaped mass. X-ray abdomen was done. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyloric stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile non-bilious vomiting, the presence of an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and a single bubble sign on X-ray. It is due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

questions.text: A newborn is presenting with history of continuous drooling of saliva and frothiness in mouth, it is also associated with respiratory distress, the X ray of the child reveals the following image, what will be probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheoesophageal fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A newborn with continuous drooling, frothiness in the mouth, and respiratory distress, along with an X-ray showing a coiled NG tube and gas in the stomach, is likely to have a tracheoesophageal fistula.

questions.text: A newborn baby came with complaints of hepatitis and cataract, lethargy & hypotonia. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely to be responsible for this condition? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galactosemia due to Galactose 1 phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency presents with hepatitis, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, and is a contraindication for breastfeeding.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DNS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GABRA-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The GABRA-1 gene is a key genetic factor in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study

options.label: C
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

options.label: D
options.text: Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the hospital with an episode of acute cholecystitis. Symptoms are controlled with medical management. On ultrasound, there is a solitary gallstone of 1.5 cm. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: C
options.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list

questions.correct_answer: C. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For acute cholecystitis that has responded to medical management, the current best practice is early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission. The Tokyo guidelines recommend early cholecystectomy within 5-7 days for mild cases (Tokyo I). For this 45-year-old patient whose symptoms are controlled with medical management, proceeding with laparoscopic cholecystectomy on the next available elective list (during the same admission) is the optimal approach, as it reduces the risk of recurrent attacks while operating when inflammation has started to resolve.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Observation and regular follow-up - This is inappropriate for a patient who has already experienced acute cholecystitis. Once symptomatic complications occur, definitive surgical management is required to prevent recurrent attacks, which can be more severe and lead to additional complications.
  • • Option A. Observation and regular follow-up
  • • Option B. Elective cholecystectomy after inflammation subsides - This approach represents delayed surgery scheduled weeks to months after discharge, which is now considered an outdated practice. It increases the risk of recurrent episodes during the waiting period and can lead to more difficult surgery due to scarring and adhesions.
  • • Option B. Elective cholecystectomy after inflammation subsides
  • • Option D. Urgent open cholecystectomy - Open cholecystectomy is not the first-line approach unless laparoscopic surgery is contraindicated. For mild to moderate cases that have been medically stabilized, there is no indication for urgent open surgery, as laparoscopic approach offers less postoperative pain, shorter hospital stays, and faster recovery.
  • • Option D. Urgent open cholecystectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute cholecystitis responsive to medical management, early laparoscopic cholecystectomy during the same admission (on the next available list) is the standard of care, offering the best balance between allowing initial inflammation to subside while preventing recurrent attacks.

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Globin gene sequencing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Globin gene sequencing is the definitive test for diagnosing thalassemia, a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin production.

questions.text: Which of the following fits into the criteria of severe variable deceleration, variations less than: (AIIMS NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: 90 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 80 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 100 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

questions.correct_answer: D. 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe variable decelerations are defined by a fetal heart rate dropping to less than 70 beats per minute for at least 60 seconds, typically due to umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

questions.text: Anenecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in which week of gestation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4th week

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ananecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in 4 th week of gestation.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/ L, majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a CSF glucose level of 70 mg dL & blood glucose level - 300 mg dL). How will you manage the index case? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vancomycin + ceftriaxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vancomycin combined with a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone is the recommended initial treatment for suspected bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: A 1-day old neonate presented with scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress and mediastinal shift. All of the following can be done except? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical signs of diaphragmatic hernia, such as a scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, and mediastinal shift. Understand the appropriate interventions, including oxygen administration, positive pressure ventilation, endotracheal intubation, and the limitations of bag and mask ventilation in specific clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: D. Weight for height less than - 3SD
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

questions.text: What is the mid arm circumference for severe acute malnutrition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 11.5 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute malnutrition is defined as
  • ➤ Weight for height <-3 standard deviation Mid upper arm circumference <11.5cm Bilateral pedal edema
  • ➤ Weight for height <-3 standard deviation
  • ➤ Mid upper arm circumference <11.5cm
  • ➤ Bilateral pedal edema

questions.text: Match the following developmental milestones: ( INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Memorize the typical age ranges for key developmental milestones in infants, such as transferring objects, social smiling, pincer grasp, and walking.

questions.text: A 3-week neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrocortisone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Hydrocortisone is the first-line treatment for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) with 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which presents with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension in neonates.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bladder exstrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy presents as an exposed, inside-out bladder on the abdominal wall, often associated with continuous dribbling of urine, especially in female newborns with epispadias and bifid clitoris.

questions.text: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as developmental delay? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Feeding by spoon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The absence of feeding with a spoon by 24 months can indicate a developmental delay in social and motor skills in a child.

questions.text: A child presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent infection. Physical examination shows height for age < -2 SD. What is the appropriate term for the above mentioned condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stunting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the different indicators of malnutrition, specifically recognizing that height for age < -2 SD is a sign of stunting, which reflects chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: Handedness is seen at the age of? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At the age of 3 years, handedness is seen.

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement in a 3-days old baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams? ( FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a 3-day-old preterm baby weighing less than 1500 grams, the fluid requirement is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This ensures proper hydration and metabolic support during this critical period.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom of severe dehydration? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thirsty child.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thirsty child indicates some dehydration, whereas signs like drowsiness, slow skin pinch retraction, and a sunken fontanelle are indicative of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022) Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence. Cotrimoxazole is not given. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: In which disease among the following, Chloride level in sweat is evaluated? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The chloride level in sweat is evaluated to diagnose cystic fibrosis, where elevated levels indicate the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Enteroviruses are the most common cause of viral meningoencephalitis in children. These viruses are a leading cause of viral infections affecting the central nervous system, particularly in children. They typically cause a range of symptoms from mild febrile illness to severe meningoencephalitis. While other viruses like mumps, arboviruses, and HSV can also cause meningoencephalitis, enteroviruses are the most frequently identified causative agents in pediatric cases.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mumps: While it can cause meningoencephalitis, it is less common than enterovirus.
  • • Option A. Mumps:
  • • Option B. Arbovirus: These viruses are important causes of epidemic encephalitis but are not the most common in children.
  • • Option B. Arbovirus:
  • • Option C. HSV: Herpes simplex virus is a significant cause of sporadic encephalitis but not the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.
  • • Option C. HSV:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enteroviruses are the most common cause of meningoencephalitis in children.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.correct_answer: B. Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.
